entry.title: RC - day 52
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • fixed my local Zulip instance
  • learned more Vagrant
  • check-out
  • coursework on algorithms and effective thinking
  • signed-up to facilitate interview prep

Focusing on my Outreachy application, I’ve managed to understand Vagrant better and fix my local Zulip instance with Cihan’s help. And when I say fix, I mean solve a problem that didn’t exist, since my codebase has not been updated to the latest version and there were some problems that shouldn’t be there. We’ve also managed to rebase Michael’s branch locally. And by rebasing I mean making it work with his changes while they’re not working.

During the check-out I’ve talked mostly about redoing my RC jobs profile yesterday and problems with Vagrant. Comparing it to Brian’s and Jonathan’s work on their apps and Deniz’s progress with d3.js, I feel like it was an easy way out of the accountability of check-outs.

Apart from struggles with making things work, reading up about new companies for Outreachy and preparing to facilitate interview prep (because, obviously, I feel ill-equipped to test other people on their programming skills), I’ve done some progress on the algorithms and effective thinking courses. As a good starting point for ideas to hopefully come, here are the five elements of effective thinking (which sound a lot like steps for learning anything):

  • understand deeply

    Don’t face complex issues head-on; first understand simple ideas deeply. Be brutally honest about what you know and don’t know. Then see what’s missing, identify the gaps, and fill them in. There are degrees to understanding and you can always heighten yours.

  • make mistakes

    Fail to succeed. Intentionally get it wrong to inevitably get it even more right. Mistakes highlight unforeseen opportunities and holes in your understanding.

  • raise questions

    Constantly create questions to clarify and extend your understanding.

  • follow ideas

    Look back to see where ideas came from and then look ahead to discover where those ideas may lead. Following the consequences of small ideas can result in big payoffs.

  • change

    You can always improve, grow, and extract more out of your education. Change is the universal constant that allows you to get the most out of learning.

entry.title: RC - day 51
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • read up on Zulip documentation, roadmap and issues
  • had a fruitful conversation with Sumana on Outreachy
  • set up a meeting with Michael on his Zulip feature
  • planned next steps
  • check-out
  • started a course in effective thinking

As I work towards the Outreachy internship, I get more and more comfortable with thinking about the big projects and tackling them in small chunks. I’ve reread a big part of Zulip documentation, studied the roadmap and current issues, trying to figure out where my skills and expectations would fit best.

Sumana is a knowledgable, skillful and amazing person. I’ve spent with her only 1.5 hours today and not only did she help me with my Outreachy ideas and priorities, pointing out some areas my skills could be best used for, but also gave a ton of inspiration on how to grow. I’ve been getting more and more inspired thanks to:

  • Sumana’s blog
  • Tom’s work
  • Moriel’s take on RTL language support

I also think that, given my experience and skills, building features for right-to-left language support and other internationalization aspects of apps sounds like a good project to focus on, while also remembering that I want to work on more than one area, since multiple goals are more likely to help me grow.

Michael, an RC alumnus, build a stream filtering feature for Zulip and I’m meeting with him on Thursday to understand it better and be able to work on it, as to merge it with the codebase. There is also an interesting feature for counting users following a stream and I’ll look into it tomorrow, to see what I’ll need help with.

One of the next steps in the application process is to learn how to use Vagrant properly - at the moment I’m mostly running commands I don’t fully understand, which doesn’t help with troubleshooting.

Second day of check-outs worked well. The group got a little big bigger, though considering the format a 25% increase is pretty substantial and I’d say 5 people is really the limit if it’s going to work as a method for improving accountability. The more people in the group, the less engaged they are and I think engagement is the key. Same as yesterday, others have done so much I’m motivated to do more for tomorrow’s meeting.

Just to have some entertainment that doesn’t feel like wasting much time, I’ve started a course on Effective Thinking through Mathematics. Improving analytical skills is always useful and I need a break from time to time.

Also, the best quote I’ve stumbled upon today, thanks to Rose: knowledge is power - it’s measured in wats.

entry.title: RC - day 50
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • had a chat about Outreachy
  • implemented users in the Sinatra app
  • learned something about the edit distance problem
  • first check-out

The new apartment is great, but I didn’t anticipate how long it would take to get to RC in the morning. I was late for my check-in and office hours for Outreachy at Zulip. Thankfully, I’ve managed to ask the questions I’ve needed answers for and decided what contribution to start with.

That being said, I’ve not worked much on Zulip today, as I paired with Michelle on Sinatra user authentication and managed to implement users in the to-do app, as a next step for learning how to build the main app. I’ve also learned how to solve the edit distance problem from Joe, though I haven’t implemented it myself yet, so that could be a good exercise sometime soon.

I’ve also had my first check-out, best described as a check-in at the end of the day, but not as casual. Together with Deniz, Brian and Noah we discussed what we’ve done today and showed the actual code, which is the first time I’ve done it apart from pairing in a long time. Tomorrow we meet again at 6pm to review our progress, which is very motivating, considering how much they’ve all managed to do today.

entry.title: RC - day 49
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • went to the Museum of the National History
  • moved to a new place
  • tested out a few Markdown tools
  • read another book on Sinatra

In order not to be so out of sync I’ve decided to pull another all-nighter. My reasoning was to get so tired, I’ll have to go to sleep at a reasonable hour to get up early on Monday. And I won’t be late for the Museum of Natural History trip. It all went great most of the day, but now I’m too tired to go to the new apartment and sleep.

Apart from the trip and switching apartment for the next two weeks, I’ve had some quality time with RC friends and managed to play with a few Markdown tools, to get a better feeling for my app. I also read another book on Sinatra, but still require some pairing from a more experienced developer to set it up right.

New week, greater challenges!

entry.title: Museum of Natural History
entry.content:
The Museum of Natural History is ginormous. We went for a trip together and after more than three hours I haven’t seen half of it. Definitely going to come back.

click an image to see the gallery
entry.summary: The Museum of Natural History is ginormous. We went for a trip together and after more than three hours I haven’t seen half of it. Definitely going to come back.

entry.title: RC - day 48
entry.content:
Osiągnięcia:

  • porozmawiałam z Andym o pomysłach i funkcjonalnościach mojej aplikacji Mardownowej
  • zaczęłam się uczyć Emacsa
  • zrobiłam kilka tutoriali w Sinatrze

Dzisiaj skupiłam się przede wszystkim na planowaniu mojej aplikacji Markdownowej i szukaniu inspiracji. Długa rozmowa z Andym pomogła w zdefiniowaniu podstawowych i przydatnych funkcjonalności, wraz z wieloma innymi świetnymi pomysłami. Doszliśmy do wniosku, że istnieje tutaj pewne szczególne uczucie - “kocham Cię w duchu RC” - platonicznej więzi i współdzielenia radości ze wspólnej pracy i działania (po polsku brzmi to co najmniej jak swego rodzaju propaganda).

Poza ściągnięciem 12 nowych narzędzi Markdownowych i pobawienia się nimi, zaczęłam się uczyć Emacsa (edytor dla ‘prawdziwych programistów’) i postanowiłam przez kolejny tydzień pisać kod tylko przy jego pomocy, żeby sprawdzić, czemu wszyscy tak go chwalą. Pod koniec tygodnia będę miała wypracowane świadome zdanie na ten temat i poczuję się lepiej, niezależnie od tego, na co się ostatecznie zdecyduję.

Przerobiłam też kilka tutoriali do Sinatry dla potwierdzania tożsamości użytkowników, chociaż nadal nie czuję, że dobrze je rozumiem i potrafię używać.

entry.title: RC - day 47
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • took part in Wireshark workshop
  • signed up for entrepreneurship workshop
  • learned to communicate with RC API
  • planned an app for the community
  • learned to build apps in Sinatra and deploy them to Heroku
  • build a to-do list app

I didn’t suspect that becoming a full-time night-owl can be so satisfying and at the same time so completely out of sync with everyone. I sleep and rest better, but anything happening before noon is out of my reach.

The RC part of the day started late, with some much needed personal errands that took priority over interview prep, watercolours and blog meeting. Thankfully, at least I’ve made it to Mike’s second Wireshark workshop and was able to sign-up for Paul’s intense workshop on entrepreneurship next Saturday.

I wanted to simply refactor one of my old projects, but got inspired to come up with an app for RC community - a pop quiz to help learn fellow Recursers’ names. In order to do that with a minimum setup, I’ve decided to use Ruby and Sinatra, which I first had to learn.

A few hours, one pretty good tutorial and some hundred Google queries later, I’ve created and deployed a simple to-do list app on Heroku. At the moment there are no users, so I’m not taking responsibility for any content that may or may not be added by any third parties. Over the weekend I’ll add some users and authorisation, probably using the RC OAuth, just to practice before the bigger project.

In case anyone wants to try the tutorial (the app is 95% the tutorial verbatim with some CSS flavours on top), it took me some time to figure out how to deploy it to Heroku. Most helpful tips:

  • an empty postgresql database must be initiated:

    heroku addons:add heroku-postgresql

  • migratons happen in heroku console:

    heroku run console
require 'sinatra'
require 'slim'
require 'data_mapper'
require './main'
DataMapper.setup(:default, ENV['DATABASE_URL'] ||
 "sqlite3://#{Dir.pwd}/development.db")  
DataMapper.auto_migrate!

entry.title: RC - day 46
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • had a presentation about quitting
  • seen community presentations
  • took part in game night
  • refactored an old project

We officially outdid ourselves - got so lost in work, at some point we’ve realized that it’s already 6am and we should get some breakfast. My first time at a diner consisted of three huge French toasts with syrup, something to keep one full for the next 10 hours. After a quick trip to the apartment, I got back to RC to work on my Outreachy application and presentation. I’ll try to write a longer post on the latter, as soon as I figure out what’s the best way of rendering mathematical formulas in HTML.

The community presentations today were fun, some highlights:

  • Fenimore’s Music Server for streaming albums over local network (also, his music preferences seem interesting enough to dig into it just for the sake of listening to something new)
  • Harold’s EpubPress Chrome extension for turning web content into ebooks
  • Noah’s Tiny Dungeon Twitter Bot and what’s even more amazing - someone was inspired to create a Dungeon Player out of the tweets

The game night was pretty intense - there were so many new people, including a lot of alumni, that after playing a short game of Codenames and my first Go game ever (thank you Danielle!), I grabbed a pizza slice and beer to work quietly in a side room. This week has been a bit overwhelming and I felt like working on refactoring some old projects.

I’ve managed to work mostly on one of them, a tiny weather app. I first fixed the old implementation and went on to work on the new one for about two hours. I’ve encountered some little bugs, two that might be useful for future reference:

  • Chrome doesn’t accept anymore geolocation over insecure connections - easily fixed with https
  • the OpenWeatherMap.org has a secure API as a premium feature - after reading up about possible solutions (e.g. getting data from other sources, IP-based), I’ve decided to simply use crossorigin.me

I also wanted to learn something new and decided animating SVG sounds fun enough. All in all, with a few more projects to refactor, I feel pretty comfortable with tackling them over the next week or so.

entry.title: RC - day 45
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • got comfortable with Outreachy application process and narrowed down my choices to three companies
  • got a working Zulip development environment
  • productively procrastinated on a presentation
  • went for a feelings check-in
  • visited Eva and Shawn
  • signed up for a blog club and interview prep

I feel I’ve finally read enough about the Outreachy application process to feel comfortable with applying. I’ve reached out on Zulip to Sumana (experienced Outreachy mentor) and the thread helped me tremendously, especially when Alice shared her application experiences. I’ll focus on trying out the projects I’m interested in locally (or reading up about the ones that are not strictly technical), maybe even make small contributions over the weekend.

Instead of simply procrastinating, I’ve managed to focus on science behind making decisions and quitting, inspired by an article on optimal stopping. I have some slides for tomorrow, but I’m not yet sure if I’m going to present - it’s not entirely a technical topic. Though knowing when to quit a project seems like a useful skill for Recursers.

The feelings check-in was a blast. It’s interesting how hearing about insecurities of others helps with my own struggles.

I visited the always warm and welcoming Eva and Shawn. The baby is going to be born soon, can’t wait! Also, I might give back to my American family and help out with some web development in exchange for dinner and cheesecake.

Friday is going to be a busy day:

  • interview prep - I’ve been a bit late for prep signups, so instead of algorithms I’m just going to do regular interview questions
  • watercolours - I’ll spend some time with Nayley on the pure pleasure of playing with paints
  • blog club - we’re starting a new group at RC, encouraging each other to write more and/or better blog posts

entry.title: RC - day 44
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • stopped forcing myself to be a morning person
  • warm-up in Python
  • took a few steps to build my Markdown app
  • improved my Gmail experience
  • paired on code dojo problem with Cihan
  • took part in the improv night, a fun and amazing experience (all thanks to Sarah!)
  • had a wonderful evening with RC friends

I think it was high time to stop kidding myself - I am not nor will I ever be a morning person. Starting the day slowly and getting to RC just in time for my breakfast and 1pm check-in was the perfect solution to my motivation problems. Firstly, I got so much sleep I woke up without an alarm and wasn’t stressed about being late. Coming in during the day, seeing all those people working away on their laptops, focused, calm and going forward with their plans was my driving force for today.

Thanks to Mike, warmups are alive and well again, and I’ve had a nice half hour playing with a simple problem in Python.

I then proceeded to plan my Markdown app - the features I want to include, people to ask for help and pair with, general look and feel of it. I’ve asked Marcio for some help on getting started and will hopefully pair soon with Nick (macOS development), Andy (macOS development and Markdown) and Michelle (Markdown filtering). Can’t wait!

As for minor tweaks, I’ve spent a productive half-hour learning all the Gmail shortcuts. I have so many messages coming in every day, it’s surprising I’ve never done that before.

Cihan made it in time for code dojo and we’ve created together a working simple solution in Python and then struggled to reimplement it in Elm. About an hour after the dojo ended, a simplistic approach got implemented. I want to work more on my functional programming, since doing even the simplest things is such a struggle. It’s like relearning to ride a bike.

The improvisation night was so amazing it’s hard to describe. Sarah is such a wonderful teacher! We’ve had a lot of group and individual exercises, all of them focused on supporting each other no matter what. Improv is really about saying “yes and” to everything, I want to do more of that in programming. And a lot more improv. It could’ve also been the group - it’s not often you come up with a new theory for global warming: flying unicorns pooping ice-cream into the atmosphere (that was a very inside joke, no worries if it wasn’t clear).

After the improv I went for great (and very cheap!) vegetarian food with some of my RC friends. It was firstly about bidding farewell to Naomi, but mostly it was simply an amazing evening.

Lastly, some food for thought:

  • write it anyway
  • how to politely deal with interruptions
  • why smart people are expected to be stupid at work
  • are you a jerk?

I seem overly amazingly and wonderfully happy recently, I should work on my adjectives starting tomorrow.
